question_user: What can I ask a company for under the PDPA if I want to see my data?
question_variants: How can I request my personal data from an organisation?
What access rights do I have to my data under PDPA?
gold_answer_short: You may request access to your personal data held by the organisation and information on how it has been or may have been used or disclosed within the past year.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.21(1), individuals can request an organisation to provide their personal data in its possession or control, and information about how that data has been or may have been used or disclosed in the year preceding the request. The organisation must provide this as soon as reasonably possible, subject to other subsections limiting disclosure.

question_user: Can an organisation refuse to give me my data?
question_variants: Are there situations where an organisation doesn’t have to provide my personal data?
When can a company reject my data access request?
gold_answer_short: Yes. Organisations are not required to provide access if the request relates to matters in the Fifth Schedule, such as certain investigations or proceedings.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.21(2), an organisation is not required to provide personal data or related information if it falls under matters listed in the Fifth Schedule. These exceptions protect sensitive areas like ongoing investigations, legal privilege, and other specified cases.

question_user: Can a company refuse my access request if giving the data might harm someone?
question_variants: Is a company allowed to withhold data if it could endanger someone?
When can a company deny my request for safety or privacy reasons?
gold_answer_short: Yes. An organisation must not provide data if doing so could threaten someone’s safety, reveal another person’s data, or be against national interest.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.21(3), an organisation must not release personal data if doing so could endanger someone’s safety or mental health, reveal another individual’s personal data or identity without consent, or be contrary to national interest. These prohibitions override general access rights.

question_user: What if the data I requested includes other people’s information from my own activity logs?
question_variants: Can I still access user activity data that contains other people’s info?
Does PDPA let me see my activity data if it has others’ data too?
gold_answer_short: Yes. The restriction on revealing another individual’s personal data does not apply to your own user activity or user-provided data.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.21(3A), subsections (3)(c) and (d) do not prevent an organisation from giving you access to user activity data about you or user-provided data from you, even if it includes other individuals’ personal data. This allows you to access your own activity information.

question_user: Will a company tell me if it shared my data with the police?
question_variants: Can an organisation disclose if it sent my data to law enforcement?
Does a company have to tell me if my data was given to authorities?
gold_answer_short: No. Organisations must not tell you about disclosures to prescribed law enforcement agencies made without your consent under the law.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.21(4), if an organisation has disclosed personal data to a prescribed law enforcement agency without your consent under this or another written law, it must not inform you of that disclosure when responding to your access request.

question_user: If some of my data cannot be disclosed, will I still get the rest?
question_variants: Can the organisation give me partial access to my data?
Will I get the parts of my data that can be released?
gold_answer_short: Yes. The organisation must provide you with the data that can be disclosed, excluding restricted parts.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.21(5), when an organisation can provide your personal data without including information excluded under subsections (2), (3), and (4), it must do so. You will receive the accessible portions while restricted parts are withheld.

question_user: If my access request is rejected, does the organisation need to tell me why?
question_variants: Will the company explain when my request is refused?
What happens if they reject my data access request?
gold_answer_short: Yes. The organisation must notify you of the rejection within the prescribed time and requirements.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.21(6), when an organisation denies your access request under subsection (2) or (3), it must inform you within the prescribed period and in the prescribed manner that your request was rejected. This ensures transparency about the decision.

question_user: If part of my data is excluded from disclosure, must the organisation tell me that?
question_variants: Will they notify me if certain data is withheld?
Do I get told when some data is excluded?
gold_answer_short: Yes. If data is withheld under certain subsections, the organisation must notify you of the exclusion.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.21(7), when an organisation provides access to your data under subsection (5) but excludes some parts under subsections (2) or (3), it must notify you that such data was excluded. This applies to requests made on or after 1 February 2021.

question_user: Can I ask a company to correct errors in my personal data?
question_variants: How can I fix mistakes in my data held by a company?
Does PDPA allow me to correct wrong personal data?
gold_answer_short: Yes. You may request an organisation to correct any error or omission in your personal data.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.22(1), individuals have the right to request an organisation to correct inaccuracies or omissions in their personal data that the organisation holds or controls. This helps ensure that the personal data remains accurate and complete.

question_user: If I request access to my data but also want it corrected, do I need two separate requests?
question_variants: Can I combine access and correction requests?
Do I have to make different requests to see and fix my data?
gold_answer_short: The PDPA separates access and correction rights, but you may make both types of requests concurrently to the same organisation.
gold_answer_extended: While PDPA s.21(1) and s.22(1) govern access and correction respectively, the Act does not prevent an individual from submitting both requests together. The organisation must handle each according to its relevant provision and time limits.

question_user: What if the organisation delays for months before replying to my access request?
question_variants: How long can a company take to respond to my PDPA data request?
Is there a time limit for access requests?
gold_answer_short: The PDPA requires organisations to respond as soon as reasonably possible, but it does not define a strict number of days in this excerpt.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.21(1), organisations must respond to access requests as soon as reasonably possible. However, this excerpt does not specify an exact timeframe. Prescribed regulations may set limits elsewhere.
